facts.text: Shah Abdul Rahim died on 26 September 1905 leaving four sons and two daughters.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ray, J.-This is an appeal by certificate against the judge- ment dated 15 December, 1965 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court dismissing the appellants suit and setting aside, the decree in favour of the appellant passed by the Additional Chief Judge, City Civil Court, Hyderabad on 18 October, 1958. Shah Abdul Rahim a resident of the pity of Hyderabad died on 26 September, 1905 leaving behind him four sons Abdul Hai, Ghulam Nooruddin, Abdul Razak and Ghulam Ghouse Mohiuddin and two daughters Kamarunnissa Begum and Badiunnissa Begum.

facts.text: Sons and daughters entered into two agreements in July 1908 appointing arbitrators to partition Matrooka properties.

anchor.surface_text: Shah Abdul Rahim had large movable and immovable properties. Me sons and the daughters entered into two agreements in the month of July, 1908 and appointed arbitrators to partition the Matrooka properties of Syed Shah Abdul Rahim.

facts.text: Arbitrators made an award partitioning properties on 1 August 1908.

anchor.surface_text: On 1 August, 1908 the arbitrators made an Award partitioning, the properties.

facts.text: Decree in Darul Khaza Court confirming award on 13 August 1908.

anchor.surface_text: On 13 August, 190 8 there was a decree in the Darul Khaza Court, Hyderabad companyfirming the Award of 1 August, 1908.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit on 24 July 1941 for setting aside 1908 decree and partitioning properties.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed the suit out of which the appeal arises on 24 July, 1941 for setting aside the decree dated 13 August, 1908 companyfirming the award and for partitioning certain Matrooka properties.

facts.text: Suit dismissed in 1942; appeal filed to High Court of Hyderabad in 1943.

anchor.surface_text: In 1942, the suit was dismissed. An appeal was preferred to the High Court of Hyderabad. During the pendency of the appeal Abdul Hai died in 1950 and his legal representatives were brought on the record of the suit in the month of February, 1952.

facts.text: Abdul Hai died in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal Abdul Hai died in 1950 and his legal representatives were brought on the record of the suit in the month of February, 1952.

facts.text: Appeal disposed by High Court of Andhra Pradesh in April 1957 remanding case to City Civil Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal filed in the year 1943 was disposed of by the High Court of Andhra Pradesh in April 1957 remanding the case to the City Civil Court, Hyderabad.

facts.text: City Civil Court decreed suit in favour of appellant on 18 October 1958, cancelling 1908 decree.

anchor.surface_text: On 18 October, 1958 the Additional Chief Judge, City Civil Court, Hyderabad decreed the suit in favour of the appellant and cancelled the decree of the Darul Khaza Court dated 13 August, 1908.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court on 15 December 1965 set aside the decree.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Andhra Pradesh High Court on 15 December, 1965 set aside the decree passed by the Additional Chief Judge.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court: Civil Appeal No. 219 of 1967 by certificate.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 219 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 16, 1965 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in C.C-C. Appeal No. 24 of 1969.

facts.text: When Abdul Rahim died in 1905, Abdul Hai was major, appellant was minor.

anchor.surface_text: The undisputed facts are these When Abdul Rahim died in 1905 Abdul Hai the eldest son was major. The appellant was a minor.

facts.text: Appellant represented by brother Ghulam Nooruddin as guardian in arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: Before the arbitrators the appellant a minor was represented by his brother Ghulam Nooruddin as the guardian.

facts.text: Parties to arbitration: Abdul Hai, Ghulam Nooruddin, Abdul Razak (appellant by guardian), two sisters.

anchor.surface_text: The parties to the arbitration agreements were Abdul Hai, Ghulam Nooruddin, Abdul Razak the appellant represented by his guardian Nooruddin, Qamarunnissa Begum and Badiunnisa Begum.

facts.text: No dispute before arbitrators; no issues framed.

anchor.surface_text: It will appear from the award that before the arbitrators there was numberdispute ,between the parties and the arbitrators did number think it necessary to frame any issues.

facts.text: Plaintiffs relinquished title to properties B-1 to B-10 marked as Khankah and Dargah properties.

anchor.surface_text: Before the arbitrators the plaintiffs marked with the letter F a plan showing properties attached to the Khankah and Dargah and those properties were market as Exhibits B-1 to B-10 and the plaintiffs relinquished their title-to properties marked Exhibits B-1 to B-10 and further stated neither at present number in future will they have any share and right in the said property.

facts.text: Abdul Hai was Sajjada Nashin in possession of Dargah and Khankah properties.

anchor.surface_text: As to properties marked B-1 to B-10 the parties stated ,before the arbitrators that Abdul Hai was the Sajjada Nashin of the Dargah and was in possession of, the Dargah and khankah properties.

facts.text: Award made rule of court on plaint by Nooruddin, Abdul Razak (by guardian), sisters vs Abdul Hai.

anchor.surface_text: The award was made a rule of companyrt within a short time upon a plaint filed by Nooruddin, Abdul Razak, the appellant represented by Nooruddin as the guardian and the two sisters Qamarunnisa Begum and Badiunnisa Begum. The defendant was Abdul Hai.

facts.text: Appellant impeached award and decree for lack of lawful guardian.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant impeached the award and the decree upon the award inter alia on the grounds that the award was void by reason of lack of lawful guardian on behalf of the appellant to protect ,and represent the rights and interests of the minor in the arbitration proceedings and in the proceedings resulting in the decree upon the award.

facts.text: Appellant claimed properties B-1 to B-10 not Dargah/Khankah but Matrooka, discovered in 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also claimed that the award and the decree should be avoided because the properties marked Exhibits B-1 to B-10 were number Dargah and Khankah properties in fact and were treated in the award and the decree to be Dargah and Khankah on the wrongful representation of Abdul Hai. The, appellant in the year 1938 discovered for the first time the true and companyrect facts that the same were number Khankah and Dargah properties

facts.text: Trial court held award/decree obtained by fraud, set aside decree, preliminary partition decree.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court held that the award and the decree thereon were obtained by fraud and the decree was to be set aside. ... The trial Court therefore passed a decree for cancellation of the decree passed upon the award and passed a preliminary decree for partition of the Matrooka properties including the properties marked as. Exhibits B-1 to B-10 in the award.

facts.text: High Court held arbitration void due to no lawful guardian, but suit barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court Held that the reference to the arbitration and the a ward thereon were void The High Court held that the decree of the Darul Khaza Court upon the award was number a nullity and the present suit should have been filed within three years of the appellant obtaining majority. ... Therefore, the suit was barred by limitation.

facts.text: Brother Nooruddin not lawful guardian under Mohammedan Law.

anchor.surface_text: The minority of the appellant is a fact found both by the trial ,Court and the High Court. It is an admitted fact that the appellants guardian was his brother Nooruddin at the time of the arbitration proceedings and at the time of the decree on the award. The brother is number a lawful guardian under the Mohammedan Law.

facts.text: Arbitration agreement, award, decree void due to lack of legal guardian.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear on the authority of this decision that the arbitration agreement and the award and the decree  1  1952 S.C.R. 1133.  2  45 T.A. 73 are all void in the present case by reason of lack of legal guardian of the appellant.

facts.text: Abdul Hai letter dated 13 August 1938 (P-8) denied properties were waqf/Dargah.

anchor.surface_text: In the letter dated 13, August, 1938 Exhibit P-8 Abdul Hai denied that the property was waqf property belonging to the Dargah and asserted that it was. owned and possessed by him and relinquished by his relatives.

facts.text: Properties attached by Nizam Govt in 1927, released same year except two villages.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the appellant was aware of the attachment of the personal and the Dargah and Khankah properties by the Government of the Nizam in the year 1927 as also release in the same year of the properties attached.

facts.text: Appellant discovered true nature in 1938/1941 from letter, demanded partition.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of the appellant was that in 1350 Fasli companyres- ponding to the year 1941 the appellant came to know that a letter had been written by Abdul Hai to the Ecclesiastical Department of the Government of the Nizam in the year 1938 ... Thereupon the appellant demanded from Abdul Hai partition of the property as Matrooka.

facts.text: Govt of Nizam in 1927 held only Debser and Sangvi villages Dargah properties; others released.

anchor.surface_text: The Ecclesiastical Department by Letter dated 28 December, 1927 held that only the villages Debser and Sangvi were found to be under the Dargah. All properties of the parties which had been attached by the Nizam were released by letter dated 3 January, 1928 excepting the two villages.

facts.text: Properties B-1 to B-10 not Dargah/Khankah but Matrooka.

anchor.surface_text: It is established in evidence that the properties which wore ,described as. Dargah and Khankah properties before the arbitrators and the decree of the Darul Khaza Court are number Dargah and Khankah properties.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepts appeal, restores trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we accept the appeal and set aside the judgment of the High Court and restore the judgment and decree of the trial companyrt. The appellant will be entitled to companyts of this Court.

The brother is number a lawful guardian under the Mohammedan Law. The legal guardians are the father, the executor appointed by the fathers will, the fathers father and the executor appointed by the will of the fathers father. No other relation is entitled to the guardianship of the property of a minor as of right. Neither the mother number the brother is a lawful guardian though the father ,or the paternal grand father of the minor may appoint the mother, brother or any other person as executor or executrix. In default ,of legal guardians a duty of appointing guardian for the protection and preservation of the minors property is of the companyrt on proper application.

concepts.interpretation: Brother is not a lawful guardian under Mohammedan Law; legal guardians limited to father, paternal grandfather, their executors; court appoints in default; hence no valid representation of minor.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 of the Limitation Act, 1908 provides that when a person having a right to institute a suit has by means of fraud been kept from the knowledge of such right or of the title on which it is founded, the time limited for instituting a suit against the person guilty of the fraud shall be companyputed from the time when the fraud first became known to the person affected thereby.

concepts.interpretation: Time for suit computed from knowledge of fraud where plaintiff kept ignorant by fraud; applies to suit challenging decree on fraud.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: covered it. There was active properties were Matrooka and number Dargah and Khankah. When Abdul Hai got the properties released by reason of the decis

concepts.unlisted_description: Exclusion of time in cases of fraud

anchor.surface_text: Possession by one companyowner is number by itself adverse to other companyowners. On the companytrary, possession by one companyowner is presumed to be the possession of all the companyowners unless it is established that the possession of the companyowner is in denial of title of companyowners and the possession is in hostility to companyowners by exclusion of them. [...] Ouster is an unequivocal act of assertion of title. There has to be open denial of title to the parties who are entitled to it by excluding and ousting them.

concepts.interpretation: No ouster unless unequivocal denial of title and exclusion; mere possession by co-owner presumed for all unless hostility proven; no evidence here.

anchor.surface_text: The estate of a deceased Mohamedan devolves on his heirs at the moment of his death. The heirs succeed to the estate as tenants in companymon in specific shares.

concepts.interpretation: Muslim heirs succeed as tenants-in-common to specific shares immediately on death; limitation from ouster.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Abdur Rahim was however dismissed and the matter was number allowed to be reopened on the strength of the orders of the Government recited by Abdu

anchor.surface_text: In Mohammedan Law the doctrine of partial partition is number applicable because the heirs are tenants-in-common and the heirs of the deceased Muslim succeed to the definite fraction of every part of his estate.

concepts.interpretation: No partial partition under Mohammedan law; full division by metes and bounds per fixed shares on partition.

anchor.surface_text: In Birth v. Birch 1  the Court of Appeal held that a judgment will be set aside on the ground of fraud if evidence of facts discovered since the judgment raise a reasonable probability of the success of the action.

concepts.interpretation: Decree set aside on fraud if post-judgment discovered facts create reasonable probability of success; time runs from knowledge of fraud.

arguments.claim: Cause of action for partition perpetually recurring; no partial partition under Mohammedan Law

anchor.surface_text: The cause of action for partition of properties is said to be a perpetually recurring one... In Mohammedan Law the doctrine of partial partition is number applicable because the heirs are tenants-in-common...

holdings.text: The brother is not a lawful guardian under the Mohammedan Law. The legal guardians are the father, the executor appointed by the fathers will, the fathers father and the executor appointed by the will of the fathers father. No other relation is entitled to the guardianship of the property of a minor as of right.

anchor.surface_text: The brother is number a lawful guardian under the Mohammedan Law. The legal guardians are the father, the executor appointed by the fathers will, the fathers father and the executor appointed by the will of the fathers father. No other relation is entitled to the guardianship of the property of a minor as of right. Neither the mother number the brother is a lawful guardian though the father ,or the paternal grand father of the minor may appoint the mother, brother or any other person as executor or executrix. In default ,of legal guardians a duty of appointing guardian for the protection and preservation of the minors property is of the companyrt on proper application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies established Mohammedan Law on hierarchy of natural guardians for minor's property; brother excluded unless appointed executor.

holdings.text: The arbitration agreement and the award and the decree are all void in the present case by reason of lack of legal guardian of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear on the authority of this decision that the arbitration agreement and the award and the decree  1  1952 S.C.R. 1133.  2  45 T.A. 73 are all void in the present case by reason of lack of legal guardian of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedent in Mohd. Amin v. Vakil Ahmed; agreement void ab initio even binding majors due to invalid minor representation.

holdings.text: There is no order for appointment of a guardian. Further, the Court in appointing the guardian of property of a minor is guided by circumstances for the welfare of the minor.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel on behalf of the respondent relied on a companyy of an application... There is numberorder for appointment of a guardian. Further, the Court in appointing the guardian of property of a minor is guided by circumstances for the welfare of the minor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examines record; application sought permission to sue, no appointment order; court appointments prioritize minor welfare.

holdings.text: The relinquishment of property by Nooruddin on behalf of the minor is not binding on the minor. There was no legal sanction behind such compromise in the arbitration and in the proceedings resulting in a decree upon the award. There was no legal guardian. The rights and interests of the minor were also not protected particularly when there was conflict of interest between the minor and Abdul Hai.

anchor.surface_text: The relinquishment of property by Nooruddin on behalf of the minor is number binding on the minor. There was numberlegal sanction behild such companypromise in the arbitration and in the proceedings result- ing in a decree upon the award. There was numberlegal guardian. The rights and interests of the minor were also number protected particularly when there was companyflict of interest between the minor and Abdul Hai.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No guardian, conflict of interest; compromise lacks legal sanction, violates minor protection.

holdings.text: The period of limitation for the suit does not run against him from the date of the death of the deceased but from the date of express ouster or denial of title and Article 144 of Schedule 1 to the Limitation Act, 1908 would be the relevant Article.

anchor.surface_text: the period of limitation for the suit does number run against him from the date of the death of the deceased but from the date of express ouster or denial of title and Article 144 of Schedule 1 to the Limitation Act, 1908 would be the relevant Article.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Muslim heirs tenants-in-common; limitation starts on ouster, applies Art.144.

holdings.text: It is established in evidence that the properties which were described as Dargah and Khankah properties before the arbitrators and the decree of the Darul Khaza Court are not Dargah and Khankah properties.

anchor.surface_text: It is established in evidence that the properties which wore ,described as. Dargah and Khankah properties before the arbitrators and the decree of the Darul Khaza Court are number Dargah and Khankah properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence including govt letters 1927-28, Abdul Hai's admissions confirm Matrooka nature.

holdings.text: A judgment will be set aside on the ground of fraud if evidence of facts discovered since the judgment raise a reasonable probability of the success of the action.

anchor.surface_text: In Birth v. Birch 1  the Court of Appeal held that a judgment will be set aside on the ground of fraud if evidence of facts discovered since the judgment raise a reasonable probability of the success of the action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows English precedent Birch v. Birch; new facts (Matrooka character) probable success.

holdings.text: Section 18 of the Limitation Act, 1908 provides that when a person having a right to institute a suit has by means of fraud been kept from the knowledge of such right or of the title on which it is founded, the time limited for instituting a suit against the person guilty of the fraud shall be computed from the time when the fraud first became known to the person affected thereby.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 of the Limitation Act, 1908 provides that when a person having a right to institute a suit has by means of fraud been kept from the knowledge of such right or of the title on which it is founded, the time limited for instituting a suit against the person guilty of the fraud shall be companyputed from the time when the fraud first became known to the person affected thereby.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fraud concealed true property character; knowledge only 1941 via letter; time excludes prior period.

holdings.text: Possession by one coowner is not by itself adverse to other coowners. On the contrary, possession by one coowner is presumed to be the possession of all the coowners unless it is established that the possession of the coowner is in denial of title of coowners and the possession is in hostility to coowners by exclusion of them. Ouster is an unequivocal act of assertion of title. There has to be open denial of title to the parties who are entitled to it by excluding and ousting them.

anchor.surface_text: Possession by one companyowner is number by itself adverse to other companyowners. On the companytrary, possession by one companyowner is presumed to be the possession of all the companyowners unless it is established that the possession of the companyowner is in denial of title of companyowners and the possession is in hostility to companyowners by exclusion of them. [...] Ouster is an unequivocal act of assertion of title. There has to be open denial of title to the parties who are entitled to it by excluding and ousting them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of denial/exclusion/ouster by Abdul Hai against co-heirs.

holdings.text: Abdul Hai knew the real character, concealed the true character and suggested a different character and thereby mislead all the parties. Again, when Abdul Hai approached the Government of the Nizam and got the properties released by asserting that they were not Dargah and Khankah properties in the year 1927. Abdul Hai did not inform the same to any of the parties.

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Hai knew the real character, companycealed the true character and suggested a different character and thereby mislead all the parties. Again, when Abdul Hai approached the Government of the Nizam and got the properties released by asserting that they were number Dargah and Khankah properties in the year 1927. Abdul Hai did number inform the same to any of the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misrepresented Matrooka as Dargah to arbitrators; concealed 1927 govt release confirming Matrooka.

holdings.text: The estate of a deceased Mohamedan devolves on his heirs at the moment of his death. The heirs succeed to the estate as tenants in common in specific shares.

anchor.surface_text: The estate of a deceased Mohamedan devolves on his heirs at the moment of his death. The heirs succeed to the estate as tenants in companymon in specific shares.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard Mohammedan inheritance law; supports no limitation from death.

holdings.text: In Mohammedan Law the doctrine of partial partition is not applicable because the heirs are tenants-in-common and the heirs of the deceased Muslim succeed to the definite fraction of every part of his estate.

anchor.surface_text: In Mohammedan Law the doctrine of partial partition is number applicable because the heirs are tenants-in-common and the heirs of the deceased Muslim succeed to the definite fraction of every part of his estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explains full partition required by shares; supports reopening entire partition.

holdings.text: For these reasons we accept the appeal and set aside the judgment of the High Court and restore the judgment and decree of the trial court. The appellant will be entitled to costs of this Court.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we accept the appeal and set aside the judgment of the High Court and restore the judgment and decree of the trial companyrt. The appellant will be entitled to companyts of this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Void arbitration/decree due to guardian/fraud; no limitation bar; properties partitionable; restores partition decree.

precedents.citation: Mohd. Amin Ors. v. Vakil Ahmed Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: It was held by this Court in Mohd. Amin Ors. v. Vakil Ahmed Ors.  1  relying on the dictum in Imambandi v. Mutsaddi 2  that where disputes arose relating to succession to the estate of a deceased Mohammedan between his three sons, one of whom was a minor, and other relations, and a deed of settlement embodying an agreement in regard to the distribution of the properties belonging to the estate was executed by and between the parties, the eldest son acting as guardian for and on behalf of the minor son the deed was number binding on the minor son as his brother was number his legal guardian and the deed was void number only qua the minor, but with regard to all the parties including those who were sui juris.

precedents.cited_proposition: eldest brother acting as guardian for minor son in settlement of estate is not legal guardian under Mohammedan law and deed is void not only qua minor but all parties
precedents.cited_holding: the deed was number binding on the minor son as his brother was number his legal guardian and the deed was void number only qua the minor, but with regard to all the parties including those who were sui juris

anchor.surface_text: It was held by this Court in Mohd. Amin Ors. v. Vakil Ahmed Ors.  1  relying on the dictum in Imambandi v. Mutsaddi 2  that where disputes arose relating to succession to the estate of a deceased Mohammedan between his three sons, one of whom was a minor, and other relations, and a deed of settlement embodying an agreement in regard to the distribution of the properties belonging to the estate was executed by and between the parties, the eldest son acting as guardian for and on behalf of the minor son the deed was number binding on the minor son as his brother was number his legal guardian and the deed was void number only qua the minor, but with regard to all the parties including those who were sui juris.

precedents.cited_proposition: dictum on legal guardianship under Mohammedan law in succession disputes where brother acts for minor

anchor.surface_text: In Birth v. Birch 1  the Court of Appeal held that a judgment will be set aside on the ground of fraud if evidence of facts discovered since the judgment raise a reasonable probability of the success of the action. The principle can be stated in the words of Westbury, L.C. in Rolfe v. Gregory 2  when the remedy is given on the ground of fraud, it is governed by this important principle, that the right of the party defrauded is number affected by lapse--of time, or generally speaking by anything done or omitted to be done so long as he, remains, without any fault of his own, in ignorance of the fraud that has been companymitted .

precedents.cited_proposition: judgment set aside on fraud if new facts raise probability of success
precedents.cited_holding: a judgment will be set aside on the ground of fraud if evidence of facts discovered since the judgment raise a reasonable probability of the success of the action

anchor.surface_text: In Birth v. Birch 1  the Court of Appeal held that a judgment will be set aside on the ground of fraud if evidence of facts discovered since the judgment raise a reasonable probability of the success of the action. The principle can be stated in the words of Westbury, L.C. in Rolfe v. Gregory 2  when the remedy is given on the ground of fraud, it is governed by this important principle, that the right of the party defrauded is number affected by lapse--of time, or generally speaking by anything done or omitted to be done so long as he, remains, without any fault of his own, in ignorance of the fraud that has been companymitted .

precedents.cited_proposition: right of defrauded party not affected by lapse of time if ignorant of fraud without fault
precedents.cited_holding: when the remedy is given on the ground of fraud, it is governed by this important principle, that the right of the party defrauded is number affected by lapse--of time, or generally speaking by anything done or omitted to be done so long as he, remains, without any fault of his own, in ignorance of the fraud that has been companymitted

precedents.citation: Biman Chandra Datta v. Promotha Nath Ghose 3

anchor.surface_text: This decision was referred to by the Calcutta High Court in Biman Chandra Datta v. Promotha Nath Ghose 3  where the dictum of Westbury, L.C. was restated by holding that where a plaintiff had been kept from knowledge, by the defendant, of the circumstances companystituting the fraud, the plaintiff companyld rely upon section 18 of the Limitation Act to escape from the bar of limitation.

precedents.case_name: Biman Chandra Datta v. Promotha Nath Ghose
precedents.cited_proposition: plaintiff kept from knowledge of fraud by defendant can rely on section 18 Limitation Act
precedents.cited_holding: where a plaintiff had been kept from knowledge, by the defendant, of the circumstances companystituting the fraud, the plaintiff companyld rely upon section 18 of the Limitation Act to escape from the bar of limitation

anchor.surface_text: In Rahim boy v. Turner 1  Lord Hobliouse said When a man has companymitted a fraud and has got property thereby it is for him to show that the person injured by his fraud and suing to recover the property has had clear and definite knowledge of those facts which companystitute the fraud, at a time which is too remote to allow him to bring the suit.

precedents.cited_proposition: fraud perpetrator must show injured party had clear knowledge of fraud facts beyond limitation period
precedents.cited_holding: When a man has companymitted a fraud and has got property thereby it is for him to show that the person injured by his fraud and suing to recover the property has had clear and definite knowledge of those facts which companystitute the fraud, at a time which is too remote to allow him to bring the suit

anchor.surface_text: In Birth v. Birch 1  the Court of Appeal held that a judgment will be set aside on the ground of fraud if evidence of facts discovered since the judgment raise a reasonable probability of the success of the action.

edges.explanation: Holding h8 states and applies the provisions of Section 18 of the Limitation Act, 1908

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 of the Limitation Act, 1908 provides that when a person having a right to institute a suit has by means of fraud been kept from the knowledge of such right or of the title on which it is founded, the time limited for instituting a suit against the person guilty of the fraud shall be companyputed from the time when the fraud first became known to the person affected thereby.
For these reasons we accept the appeal and set aside the judgment of the High Court and restore the judgment and decree of the trial court. The appellant will be entitled to costs of this Court.

edges.explanation: Holding that possession by one co-owner is presumed for all unless otherwise proven directly addresses whether Abdul Hai's possession was ouster against co-owners.

anchor.surface_text: Possession by one companyowner is number by itself adverse to other companyowners. On the companytrary, possession by one companyowner is presumed to be the possession of all the companyowners unless it is established that the possession of the companyowner is in denial of title of companyowners and the possession is in hostility to companyowners by exclusion of them. [...] Ouster is an unequivocal act of assertion of title. There has to be open denial of title to the parties who are entitled to it by excluding and ousting them.
For these reasons we accept the appeal and set aside the judgment of the High Court and restore the judgment and decree of the trial court. The appellant will be entitled to costs of this Court.
